name: 3-chloro-2-nitrobenzoic_acid
source: Aldrich Chemical Company; Aldrich Catalog-Handbook of Fine Chemicals; Milwaukee; WI; 1984.

name: 3-chloro-2-nitrobenzoic_acid
source: Aldrich Chemical Company; Aldrich Catalog-Handbook of Fine Chemicals; Milwaukee; WI; 1984.
Reason: The basic unit, benzene, has a melting point of 5.5°C. The presence of a carboxylic acid group (-COOH) substantially increases the melting point due to the ability to form strong intermolecular hydrogen bonds; this can increase the melting point by approximately +200°C. The chloro substituent (Cl) is electron-withdrawing and also participates in intermolecular interactions, potentially increasing the melting point by around +5°C. The nitro group (-NO2) is a strong electron-withdrawing group and tends to increase the melting point significantly due to increased polarity and the potential for intermolecular interactions, contributing potentially another +20 to +30°C. Combining these effects, we can predict an increase in the melting point due to the combined electron-withdrawing effects and the ability to form strong hydrogen bonds.
